awd_titl_txt: RUI: There is more to the Hox code than you thought - the role of the "Hox fin/limb building toolkit" genes in the evolution of vertebrate diversity
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the primary goals of Evolutionary Developmental Biology is to understand the genetic basis of morphological evolution. While there is intense interest in cataloging and conserving diversity in nature, we are only beginning to understand the mechanisms responsible for generating biodiversity. Fins and limbs are homologous structures that are patterned by a shared genetic repertoire of HoxA/D expression, which has been referred to as the 'Hox fin/limb building toolkit'. A unique expression pattern is associated with the most famous example of a novel limb modification that specifies digit identity and the origin of the thumb in the human hand. The pattern also occurs in fishes and sharks, indicating that it arose in the common ancestor of jawed vertebrates. Recent evidence indicates that the Hox code is more complex than previously recognized, yet few derived morphologies have been evaluated. This project examines the role of Hox genes in the evolution and development of novel fin/limb modifications in three divergent lineages that exhibit unique body plan features, and for which the ecological or physiological significance is understood. This research engages undergraduates in using genomic tools to answer newly tractable questions, and is based at a public state university that serves a large undergraduate population with a high proportion of underrepresented minorities. The focal taxa (sharks, manta rays, paddlefish and surfperches) are highly charismatic and command intense interest in the public eye. The PI has a track record of involving undergraduates in research, professional presentations, and publication, and will develop educational materials to engage the general public in understanding the genetic underpinnings of the evolution of diversity, including fin and limb modifications that share deep homology with our own hands and feet, while serving the NSF's mission of connecting research, education and public outreach. 

Vertebrates exhibit a remarkable array of fin and limb modifications that are clear homologs of human appendages, yet the genetic underpinnings of most have not been characterized. Their variety forms the basis for the observed morphological diversity in vertebrates, and their novelty provides a unique opportunity for elucidating general principles of morphological evolution. The overarching goal of this research is to evaluate the modularity and plasticity of the Hox fin/limb-building program in the evolution of morphological diversity in vertebrates by addressing the following questions: 
 - Do claspers or cephalic lobes represent independent sets of paired appendages in modern cartilaginous fishes that are patterned by the Hox fin/limb pathway genes?
 -  Are novel deployments of the Hox fin/limb pathway genes associated with morphological diversity in medial fin structures such as the genital protuberance in surfperch anal fin, or the elongated caudal fin in paddlefish?
This research will employ a functional genomic screen composed of multiple approaches including RNASeq, in situ hybridization, functional assays, and evaluation of conserved/novel regulatory sequences for the Hox fin/limb toolkit genes that are known to pattern fins/limbs in model taxa.

por.por_cntn:
This project has resulted in several examples demonstrating both modularity and plasticity of the Hox Fin/limb toolkit genes in the evolution and development of novel features in vertebrates. For example, skates have been described as having three areas of distal outgrowth corresponding to novel paired fin modifications that develop via prolonged maintenance of an apical ectodermal ridge (AER), and these AERs are specified by a simple and unexpected re-deployment of HoxA genes that are unique to each domain. An extended AER in anterior pectoral fin in batoids is specified by HoxA13, while the extended AER in anterior pelvic fin of skates is specified by HoxA11. This was surprising because HoxA11/13 typically specify posterior structures, but in the little skate they are redeployed in exclusive anterior paired fin domains to specify novel AERs maintenaned by Wnt3. HoxA specification is further supported because both anterior structures fail to develop when HoxA expression is disrupted by ectopic exposure to retinoic acid. Pelvic claspers, observed in male cartilaginous fishes, are specified by a combination of HoxA11/13, Shhand HoxD12/13 that maintains a novel AER and posterior patterning. Therefore, all three of these novel AERs are specified by a unique HoxA code. These data led us to ask the question “Are vertebrates constrained to two sets of paired appendages? The family Myliobatidae (including the manta rays and devil rays) and are considered one of the most charismatic lineages of ancestral jawed vertebrates, having captivated humans for centuries because of their unique and highly modified body plan. They have been described as the only living vertebrates with three functional paired appendages. The most derived of these appendages, the cephalic lobes, are anterior fin-like projections that evolved in association with a novel feeding mode, as the myliobatids transitioned from a benthic to pelagic lifestyle. But did cephalic lobes truly evolve independently, or are they modified anterior pectoral fins? First, we demonstrated that while cephalic fins exhibit bony/cartilagenous structures, these fin rays are not composed of new or additional fin rays compared to other batoids. Second, using a comparative transcriptomic approach, we inferred that cephalic fins are homologous with anterior pectoral fins of the little skate based on shared developmental and gene expression patterns, and concluded that cephalic fins cannot be considered independent appendages because they lack independent Hox posterior patterning. Therefore, cephalic fins arose as modified pectoral fins. Comparing differential gene expression between species with and without cephalic fins enabled us to generate a short list of candidate genes to identify the mechanism by which domain splitting arose in the mobulid ancestor via interruption of fin ray outgrowth at the AER by Dkk1. Dkk1 is a known inhibitor of the Wnt signaling pathway, which made it our top candidate for the genetic basis of AER interruption, reduced fin ray outgrowth, and domain splitting in myliobatid pectoral fins. We performed a functional test of this mechanism by ectopic exposure to DKK1 in the anterior pectoral fin of the little skate that resulted in reduced fin ray outgrowth that mimics the mobulid phenotype. While cephalic fins do not represent a third set of independent paired appendages, based on the criterion of patterning by 5’ HoxA/D genes, this path of discovery opened an interesting line of investigation. Prepelvic claspers (PPCs) only occur in males and are hidden in slits anterior to the pelvic fins. They are ornamented with dermal to aid in internal fertilization in marine environments. And we have proposed that holocephelan PPCs may represent the only extant vertebrate lineage with more than two sets of independent paired appendages based on independent Hox patterning. The project has also produced multiple examples of novel Hox expression patterns associated with medial structures in distinct lineages, including the yolk sac extension in zebrafish, a novel sphincter in gobies, and multiple modifications in medial fins. We also found a novel expression pattern of HoxA13a in a derived anal fin feature exhibited by surfperches (Embiotocidae). Surfperches are unique among vertebrates because they exhibit true pregnancy and give birth to precocious juveniles that are sexually mature (or nearly) at birth. Males have four distinct anal fin modifications that are associated with internal fertilization including a group of fin rays that exhibit cross bracing and other reinforcing struts that we call the auctis pinna followed by the paxillum, manubrium, and ramus. While surfperches exhibit proximal and distal medial fin patterning similar to paddlefish during early development later in development HoxA13a specifies the exact fin rays where the AP will develop. Taken together, these data suggest that HoxA11/13 are re-deployed during specification of a variety of novel medial fin domains.
